headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to MWV Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2009 Conference Call. [Operator Instructions]  I'd now like to turn the call over to Director of Investor Relations, Jason Thompson. Please go ahead, sir.
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to MWV Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2009 Conference Call. [Operator Instructions]  I'd now like to turn the call over to Director of Investor Relations, Jason Thompson. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Nick and good morning, everyone. This morning we announced our results before the market opened. A notification of this morning's call was broadly disclosed. Further, this morning's call is being webcast at mwv.com and slides that accompany this c
componenttext: Thanks, Nick and good morning, everyone. This morning we announced our results before the market opened. A notification of this morning's call was broadly disclosed. Further, this morning's call is being webcast at mwv.com and slides that accompany this call are available there as well.I'll briefly remind you that certain statements we make are forward-looking and are not guarantees of future performance, and are subject to known and unknown risks and uncertainties described in our public fillings. Furthermore, contents contained time-sensitive information that, although correct today, may change with the passage of time.First, a brief recap of the results we reported this morning. For the fourth quarter, we reported net income of $51 million or $0.29 per share. These results include net favorable after-tax items totaling $30 million or $0.07 per share. Now here to tell you more about our results for the fourth quarter and the full year are John Luke, Chairman and CEO; Jim Buzzard, our President; and Mark Rajkowski, CFO. I'll now turn the call over to John.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jason, thanks very much and good morning. 2009 was a good year for MWV and in an environment that is difficult for our industry and the broader economy. We set a course to manage through a challenging and uncertain economic period, and we executed on thos
componenttext: Jason, thanks very much and good morning. 2009 was a good year for MWV and in an environment that is difficult for our industry and the broader economy. We set a course to manage through a challenging and uncertain economic period, and we executed on those plans. We improved earnings and increased shareholder value by focusing on sound strategies. Strategies that worked and will enhance our overall competitiveness. This work continue. We have made choices about marketplace participation that have both increased our earnings and positioned us for greater profitability going forward. We have made improvements to our business model with a badly-needed impact on bottom line results and importantly, that will provide us greater operating leverage as demand eventually improves. And we have preserved and strengthened our sound financial position, making us standout as a stable and reliable partner to our customers in an uncertain environment, while also giving us the flexibility to invest in future growth or/and with those customers.  Continued progress in unique areas in 2010 is a high priority.  In a few moments, Jim will talk about our strong operational performance during the fourth quarter and the dynamics we see in our markets. And then Mark will highlight some of the financial metrics and outline our financial priorities as we move into 2010.Before turning to them, I want to elaborate briefly on a few aspects of our fourth quarter performance that punctuate the progress we've made on our value creation strategies during the year. First, we continue to strengthen partnerships with customers and they capitalize on our strengths to win business with new customers. We're helping major beverage customers take advantage of a growing market, from multipack packaging in Asia, and we added new customers during the quarter from Shellpak, Natralock, MWare and other innovative offerings across our marketplace.Second, our aggressive cost and productivity initiatives have resulted in a more competitive business model. We extended margins in each of our businesses during the fourth quarter, capping off the year where MWV's overall operating profitability improved significantly. This has been a dedicated and determined effort across the company. We reached our immediate targets and have set our sights on additional improvements going forward.Finally, our financial strength continues to be a valuable asset for all of our businesses, and has allowed us to meet our commitments to both customers and shareholders through a very uncertain year. We added more cash to our balance sheet during the fourth quarter, and we're gratified that we've preserved and increased shareholder value during this tremendously difficult period. As we look forward, we're expecting a continuation of the same challenges we've been facing. An increasingly stable but still weak economy, as [indiscernible] consumers and cautious customers and public policies that may stifle rather than stimulate economic growth. Despite the still uncertain market outlook, we're confident, however, that we're focused on the right things. MWV's strategy for 2010 is built on the principles that grow of our positive results in 2009. We're already working hard on another series of deliberate actions that will further strengthen our business, including a priority emphasis on growth and development geographies, especially Brazil; organic growth on most attractive end markets, particularly healthcare packaging; and additional reductions in our cost structure and refinements to our overall market participation. With continued vigilance in these areas and many more, we'll build on our recent performance record and generate additional positive momentum in 2010. I'd now like to turn the call over to Jim Buzzard to talk about our business results in the fourth quarter before Mark discusses our financial metrics, and a more detailed outlook for the first quarter as well. Jim?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. I'm pleased to say that the tremendous work we put in on both our operational performance and commercial strategies this year delivered strong results. We've taken significant steps toward our goal of world-class cost and productivity per
componenttext: Thank you, John. I'm pleased to say that the tremendous work we put in on both our operational performance and commercial strategies this year delivered strong results. We've taken significant steps toward our goal of world-class cost and productivity performance, and we're demonstrating the market knowledge and commercial excellence that will be required to turn the operating leverage we've created into dramatically-improved earning results as markets improve.Our progress this year has been apparent, even in this difficult economic environment. Sales were down about 9% across the company for the year and yet, we've increased earnings from our business segments by 24% compared to 2008. We're beginning to see some early positive signs from customers. No one expects a dramatic recovery in the near future. However, many of our markets have stabilized, and we're seeing some year-over-year improvement in order patterns. As we've noted throughout the year, our business in consumer staples such as food, beverage, healthcare and home and garden has held up as well as you might expect during this economic downturn. Whereas the luxury and consumer discretionary categories have seen more protracted declines, including personal care, fragrance and entertainment.The commercial organization we've built over the past year continues to provide improved visibility into these market dynamics. And our value-based assessment at each of our businesses has its focus on the right strategic opportunities in the most attractive end markets for our products and services. As these trends continue and our markets gain momentum, we are positioned to capitalize on our improved operating leverage. In anticipation of the severe economic challenges, we took steps to speed up and resize our strategic cost management program. We've exceeded our targets for overhead cost savings in 2009, adding together overhead cost savings, capacity actions and ongoing plant productivity initiatives, the total impact from our cost management program was more than $275 million this year. And in 2010, we expect to deliver an additional 3% to 4% of operating productivity improvement.Let me share some detail about the impact of our commercial strategies and operating productivity actions on each of our businesses and consumer packaging markets. As always, you'll find additional information in the slide presentation that accompanies this call.In the Packaging Resources business, segment profits were down only slightly during the fourth quarter despite volume decreases due to the economy, inventory control and our decision to exit certain low return business. Pricing was up year-over-year, and we experienced a modest cost deflation. However, this was offset by the impact of lost volumes. As a result, profits were down about 11% for the quarter and 7% for the year. Given the very difficult year in 2009, this was a great effort by our team. Compared to last year's fourth quarter, shipments of SBS were down 16%, but were essentially flat versus the third quarter. CNK volumes were down 9% compared to last year as several beverage customers delayed taking shipments in order to balance year-end inventories.We're gaining market share in key value-added paperboard markets, especially commercial print, tobacco in China and Japan and aseptic liquid packaging across Asia. We've also had good traction with the recent launch of our MWare line of food service products, and new business from our effort to work with brand owners to specify our products for their offerings in food markets. In addition, Rigesa continues to maintain its profitability with strong productivity gains. Our business in Brazil rebounded more quickly than elsewhere in the world. And we expect the recovery we've seen over the past several months to continue. These trends should be a tailwind for Rigesa in 2010.The Consumer Solutions segment had another strong quarter to finish a much-improved year. Profits doubled in this business during the fourth quarter, from $11 million in 2008 to $22 million in 2009, and profits for the year were up 70%. The team has done a good job reducing costs, illuminating unprofitable products and seeking out of opportunities to win with our customers in an environment that still saw a 10% overall decline in sales for the year. The rate of decline moderated in the fourth quarter, and even markets have stabilized and some of our customers are beginning to sound more optimistic about demand in 2010.Let me go through each of the consumer packaging markets we serve in this business to give you a sense of the performance in the quarter. Our Global Beverage business, sales and earnings increased again during the fourth quarter, part thanks to new business in Asia, as well as outstanding productivity at our operating facilities. Our business in China was up 50% this year, and our customers are firmly focused on this region for their future growth. We are pursuing additional opportunities to grow with these customers by helping them win with our proprietary products and machinery, both in traditional multipack markets as well as new and adjacent categories. Meanwhile, trends in the beer and soft drink business in North America and Europe have remained relatively stable. We're still seeing resiliency for beer in North America. We've even had a small increase in volume for carbonated soft drinks, which has generally been declining for the past few quarters.In our healthcare business, sales and earnings were up for the year. The focus of this business continues to be on our Shellpak solution and other adherence packaging, as well as valuable pumps for pharmaceuticals requiring nasal or oral applications. We increased our Shellpak volumes from about 3 million units per month at the beginning of the year to more than 7 million units per month in the fourth quarter, by adding new drugs for Wal-Mart's generic prescription program and adding new branded and generic pharmaceutical customers. There's also been some moderate improvement in the market for our preservative-free pumps in Europe. As customers restock inventory and concern for the benefits of this innovative application. We've added a new customer for this solution as well during the quarter, including our first few customers in India. These innovative products, as well as the recently launched Med-Easy package that we've introduced in Europe and North America, will be the central focus of our growing healthcare business in 2010.We've begun to see a small amount of progress in the global markets for personal care. Sales were up during the fourth quarter compared to last year. And the bottom really fell out of the luxury products sector, and they are beginning to emerge from a very difficult year in this business with some positive momentum. We've heard from some fragrance customers who are beginning to restock inventories as well as considering new launches for their product pipelines. And we continue to benefit from an increased emphasis on healthy habits involving hand soaps and sanitizers. We remain excited about opportunities for our innovative airless pump dispensers, a solution that helps customers lower their costs and manage their supply chains by avoiding the need to add preservatives to their formula. As in our other businesses, we've taken aggressive action to reduce costs, resize our manufacturing footprint and increase productivity in the personal care business, which has helped improved margins and raised profits during the fourth quarter and the entire year.In home and garden, activity remains positive in advance of the all-important lawn and garden maintenance season in the United States. Sales and earnings were about even in the fourth quarter, and profitability was up significantly for the entire year. We benefited from an upward trend in home and hard surface cleaning solutions this year, and recently secured an extended contract for the pre-fresh[ph] trigger sprayer we provide for Procter & Gamble's popular, the Breeze product. As I've noted before, we are actively managing our media and entertainment business with maximum cash generation, and doing so very successfully. Sales continue to decline in this business, especially for printed media and specialty packaging, and we've taken actions to rationalize capacity and costs as a result. Sales are still relatively strong for plastic injection-molded products, including our popular EcoLite DVD and Blu-Ray cases, as we've emerged as one of the media's [ph] small handful of suppliers to the major distributors[ph]. We also continue to make inroads into consumer electronics and other markets with our Natralock security packaging. The team was recently at the Consumer Electronic Show in Las Vegas, and announced several new customers with this innovative packaging, including Kodak and Swiss Army. This business should continue to expand nicely in 2010.Turning to our non-packaging businesses, our positive earnings momentum has continued in both the Consumer & Office Products and Specialty Chemicals segments. Coming off with some historic lows last year, the Consumer & Office Products segment had another solid performance in the fourth quarter to finish a very good year. We continue to benefit from strong placement and sell-through of proprietary branded consumer and office products at leading North American retailers and distributors. Our alignment and collaboration with these winning retailers led to volume increases for the all-important back-to-school and year-end planning seasons in this business. Along with some significant productivity improvements, these volume gains contribute to a strong increase in profitability for the Consumer & Office Products segment during both the quarter and the year. While the Brazilian back-to-school season is just underway, we had good initial placement for Tilibra and Grafons, whose high-end stationery products we acquired to extend our reach in the attractive Brazilian market. The integration of Grafons is well underway and is expected to contribute to earnings in 2010.Sales increased slightly in the Specialty Chemicals segment, and the business posted another increase in earnings compared to weak fourth quarter in 2008. Despite the difficult economy, we recorded strong sales in several markets, including asphalt, printing ink, adhesives and a [indiscernible] technologies for water treatment, which set a record for sales in the year. Our Auto Carbon business was also stronger than expected as North American manufacturers increased production slightly and sales in Asia nearly reached an all-time high. We continue to see momentum for our asphalt paving products around the world, including commitments in China to use Evotherm for cold weather paving.Market conditions for the Community Development & Land Management segment continued as they have throughout 2009. The overall real estate market was soft but there were some momentum in our current area of emphasis, small real [ph] land tracts. We closed 11 of these smaller transactions during the quarter, with an average price per acre of more than $2,100. Similar to last quarter ,we also closed a larger forest land sale in South Carolina, more than 10,000 acres for a total of $18 million. In total, land sales during the quarter were more than $23 million, and was a primary contributor to segment earnings of $20 million. We continue to make progress in our development activities as well. We unveiled the master plan for our large East Edisto property which was met with a very positive reaction from the community in South Carolina. We're already working with local governments on long-term development agreements and infrastructure plans, and we expect that work to continue through 2010.We also signed the previously-announced lease agreement with the tenant for our industrial and distribution park joint venture with the Rockefeller Group serving the Port of Charleston. We're actively pursuing prospective tenants for a second site on this property, as well as other industrial and development projects. The long-term dynamics for these properties are very strong, especially with the recent announcement that Boeing will open a second assembly plant for their Dreamliner aircraft in the North Charleston area, and bring as many as 10 to 15 suppliers to the region along with them. Now I would like to turn the call over to Mark to discuss some of our financial metrics for the fourth quarter. Mark?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim. During the fourth quarter, we continue to execute the game plan we laid out at the beginning of 2009 to improve our business model and strengthen our financial position. We had a strong finish to what was a year of substantial progress. As a
componenttext: Thanks, Jim. During the fourth quarter, we continue to execute the game plan we laid out at the beginning of 2009 to improve our business model and strengthen our financial position. We had a strong finish to what was a year of substantial progress. As a result, we delivered increased earnings in cash flow in both the fourth quarter and full year. More importantly, the improvement that we've made to our cost structure and financial flexibility provide us with an excellent foundation on which to build in 2010. Consider these highlights from 2009. We expanded operating margins in each of our businesses, resulting in 170 basis point improvement in the company's operating margins year-over-year. We permanently eliminated more than $150 million of overhead and fixed manufacturing costs, and we continue to make our cost structure more competitive. And we generated over $870 million of operating cash flow and added about $300 million of cash to our balance sheet. We achieved this during one of the most difficult economic environments ever.  This is a record of accomplishment of which we are proud, but not satisfied. Our plans for 2010, build on this progress in momentum. Let's take a closer look at these areas of our performance. We expanded our gross margin in each of our businesses. On an adjusted basis, we saw a total gross margin improvement of 360 basis points and 240 basis points in the fourth quarter and full year, respectively. This margin improvement reflects both the significant cost savings we generated from our overhead and manufacturing capacity actions, as well as the enhanced product mix we achieved for more focused market participation strategies that emphasize higher margin products.Much of our success during the year was driven by determined effort to implement our strategic cost management program. During the fourth quarter, we generated an additional $64 million of savings from the reduction of overhead and fixed manufacturing costs. For the year, total cost savings were $154 million, which we achieved by closing or restructuring 16 facilities and eliminating almost 3,000 positions, which is 13% of our global workforce. As a result of this progress and ongoing work to further reduce overhead costs, we continue to expect at least $250 million of run rate savings by the middle of this year.In the fourth quarter, our SG&A spend was reduced $35 million related to our overhead cost savings. This represents a 20% reduction compared to the previous year, and we will continue to benefit from these savings going forward. These reductions, however, were more than offset by higher performance-based compensation as a substantial portion of these full-year costs were accrued in the fourth quarter.Higher earnings and our ongoing working capital discipline contributed to an excellent year of cash flow generation. Excluding the impact from the alternative fuel credits and other special items, cash flow from operations was about $640 million. That's an improvement of almost 50% over 2008. Free cash flow, which is cash after CapEx and dividends, was $258 million, and we had $850 million of cash on hand at the end of 2009, also a substantial improvement.In record [ph], the strong cash performance with actions to further improve our liquidity, and financial flexibility. In 2009, we reduced outstanding debt by over $200 million, exiting the year with a total debt to capital ratio of 39%. We also took advantage of the improved credit markets to greatly increase our overall financial flexibility by optimizing our debt maturity schedule and renewing our $600 million credit facility. Our financial strength has been a clear advantage in a tough environment. We've continued to invest in innovation, we've won business with new customers looking for reliability and stability in their supply chains and of course, we were able to maintain our industry-leading dividend for our shareholders.As we look ahead to 2010, we expect another challenging year with an uneven global economic recovery. While we expect continued steady growth in Brazil, China and India, high unemployment, ongoing tight credit, a weak housing market and rising saving levels are likely to continue to depress U.S. economic growth this year. While demand has stabilized at current levels and in some markets is beginning to pick up from the lows we experienced in 2009, resiliency and trajectory of these trends through this year remains unclear. As such, we are continuing to focus on the key controllables in maintaining the priorities that drove our success in 2009, improving our business model, enhancing our financial strength and selectively investing capital to profitably grow our business.Turning to the first quarter outlook, we expect our businesses to experience typical seasonality. But we are seeing some favorable volume trends as we begin to compare to the severe declines we saw at this time last year. Backlogs at the mills are stronger and customer tone in other key packaging markets has become more positive. As a result, we expect volumes to improve modestly year-over-year. We also expect our results in the first quarter to benefit from the full run rate of the overhead and fixed manufacturing cost savings we achieved in 2009, as well as some moderation of input costs compared to last year's first quarter.Taking into account all of these factors, we expect higher year-over-year earnings in each of our business segments, with the exception of our Community Development and Land Management business which benefited last year from a single large land sale. With that, John, I'll turn it back to you.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mark, thanks very much. In summary, MWV ended the year with solid performance in the fourth quarter. We set a course at the beginning of 2009 to strengthen our competitiveness, even in a difficult and uncertain economic environment. We followed that cours
componenttext: Mark, thanks very much. In summary, MWV ended the year with solid performance in the fourth quarter. We set a course at the beginning of 2009 to strengthen our competitiveness, even in a difficult and uncertain economic environment. We followed that course, executing on plans to reduce costs, refined marketplace participation and build financial strength. These actions helped improve our earnings results, increase shareholder value and generate considerable momentum for our operations as we head further in 2010. This concludes our prepared comments this morning, and we'd now be happy to answer your questions.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of Claudia Hueston with JPMorgan.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of Claudia Hueston with JPMorgan.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jim, I think you said that some of your customers in the Consumer Solutions business were beginning to sound more optimistic. Just hoping you could elaborate on that and maybe characterize if there's any similarities any particular businesses or regions t
componenttext: Jim, I think you said that some of your customers in the Consumer Solutions business were beginning to sound more optimistic. Just hoping you could elaborate on that and maybe characterize if there's any similarities any particular businesses or regions there where you're seeing that optimism?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: As I think I noted, we are beginning to hear customers at least sounding a little more positive toned. We're seeing that certainly as they are restocking some of their inventories, the destocking we saw last year has stopped and are actually beginning to
componenttext: As I think I noted, we are beginning to hear customers at least sounding a little more positive toned. We're seeing that certainly as they are restocking some of their inventories, the destocking we saw last year has stopped and are actually beginning to move back into the supply chain. In areas like the Fragrance business, we've seen an uptick in orders and we're hearing customers talk about the fact that they're looking at new launches. Nothing definitive yet but they're beginning to see opportunities to grow their business. Other areas within personal care continue to be positive year-over-year. And then we're also seeing obviously the benefit, I think, of some our innovative packaging solutions. In the healthcare markets, we're seeing good opportunities there. I think our strength in emerging markets, China, Brazil, Eastern Europe, India are all helping leverage things as well. And then we've made some moves with our CNK products into the food markets, where we bring some real value especially in the frozen food areas as well. So it's really across the board. We're seeing better tone and tender [ph]. We're not here to declare a victory and say, that we're seeing real strength in the markets but certainly feeling better than we did this time last year.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just with respect to some of these emerging markets and opportunities for growth. Can you just talk a little bit more about the strategy as you think about emerging markets and what sort of your criteria is, if you're thinking about growth in tho
componenttext: And then just with respect to some of these emerging markets and opportunities for growth. Can you just talk a little bit more about the strategy as you think about emerging markets and what sort of your criteria is, if you're thinking about growth in those regions?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Claudia, I think that clearly our focus has been on Brazil, China, India and Eastern Europe. So we've put capital into those regions. So we have manufacturing capabilities in each of those areas. And I think it's the same philosophy we've taken in the Nor
componenttext: Claudia, I think that clearly our focus has been on Brazil, China, India and Eastern Europe. So we've put capital into those regions. So we have manufacturing capabilities in each of those areas. And I think it's the same philosophy we've taken in the North America and Western Europe. It's what sort of packaging solutions can we provide the leading global brand owners to bring value to them and help them succeed in their markets. And so whether it's growth in multipack packaging in China, where we're seeing certainly the large beverage companies make significant investments, whether it's in the personal care markets and whether it's in specialty chemicals. All those areas, we continue to participate and bring value to our customers. I think one of the things that sets us apart is that we can supply the global brand owners anywhere in the world that they choose to participate and we're doing that.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Claudia, good morning, this is John. I would just supplement what Jim was saying because I think that implicit in everything that he's saying is a very disciplined focus towards managing investment, marketplace participation, all with a view towards parti
componenttext: Claudia, good morning, this is John. I would just supplement what Jim was saying because I think that implicit in everything that he's saying is a very disciplined focus towards managing investment, marketplace participation, all with a view towards participating in areas where there are decided  opportunities for us to bring value and get rewarded as we grow profitably in those markets, and let that guide the discipline in and around the investments we make. But I think we are, as Jim reinforced, uniquely well positioned but it is a very carefully thought-out approach towards building markets.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Could you provide some CapEx and tax rate guidance for 2010?
componenttext: Could you provide some CapEx and tax rate guidance for 2010?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Claudia, in terms of CapEx. As you know, 2009, we were very much focused on preserving capital and maintaining liquidity. So as we look at this year's spend, there were certainly some delays in deferrals of projects to preserve cash. So we'd expect to see
componenttext: Claudia, in terms of CapEx. As you know, 2009, we were very much focused on preserving capital and maintaining liquidity. So as we look at this year's spend, there were certainly some delays in deferrals of projects to preserve cash. So we'd expect to see some tick up in our CapEx in 2010. The other thing that certainly we want to do is to take advantage of some of the strength that we have in key end markets and some of the emerging geographies as Jim was talking about earlier. And we're not going to get ahead of the recovery but where we see opportunities to profitably grow our business, we'll take advantage of that as well. So certainly, some modest increases over the level of spend that we have this year.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the tax rate?
componenttext: And the tax rate?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Tax rate, this is to pinpoint that is a difficult thing but I think a range to think about is somewhere in the 25% to 30% range.
componenttext: Tax rate, this is to pinpoint that is a difficult thing but I think a range to think about is somewhere in the 25% to 30% range.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mark Connelly with Sterne Agee.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mark Connelly with Sterne Agee.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: John, I wonder if we could talk about Consumer Solutions in terms of the Calmar business. I'm wondering as we move into the spring whether you see enough signs of recovery in the higher end spray pump business to offset potential seasonal losses. Purell h
componenttext: John, I wonder if we could talk about Consumer Solutions in terms of the Calmar business. I'm wondering as we move into the spring whether you see enough signs of recovery in the higher end spray pump business to offset potential seasonal losses. Purell has helped you a lot through this period. I'm just curious whether you're seeing any signs that the rest of that market is coming back? Or whether you think that the Purell type business might continue to hold you through?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mark, I will start and I'll turn it over to Jim to provide a little bit more color. I think we continue to see good focus on the Purell type business in response to all of the concerns and market development as a result that's come from that. I think the
componenttext: Mark, I will start and I'll turn it over to Jim to provide a little bit more color. I think we continue to see good focus on the Purell type business in response to all of the concerns and market development as a result that's come from that. I think the nature of our participation in the pumps and dispensers market place, and the innovation that we bring to bear has helped us be nicely positioned to play every day as well as higher end markets. Jim can as I said elaborate a little bit more definitively, but I think that we are seeing opportunities for recovery to be more manifest but I think it's really reinforced across the board. We are cautious. Our customers are cautious. They feel a little bit better than they did a year ago, but this remains an uncertain time and it would be difficult to predict what the marketplace and economic environment would really look like beyond, I guess, beyond the next several weeks no less, what it would like six months from now. But Jim can provide a little bit more color on what we're seeing.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: As we sit here today and look forward again with the caveat, as John said, that's a visibility is not all that transparent to our customers. A couple of things going on. We certainly were supported in 2009 by the Purell, other sort of soap dispensing and
componenttext: As we sit here today and look forward again with the caveat, as John said, that's a visibility is not all that transparent to our customers. A couple of things going on. We certainly were supported in 2009 by the Purell, other sort of soap dispensing and antibacterial products. But we also believe that there's been a permanent change in consumer's habits. So while it looks certainly come back from the levels we saw in 2009, we do believe that it would be a permanent uptick, one that has been in prior years just as consumer behaviors have changed. We are seeing as we enter the lawn and garden season for the high-end prune [ph] applicators which are good products for us. Strong order patterns there. And as I referenced, in the personal care markets, particularly fragrance, we are seeing improved tender [ph] from our customers and that is being reflected in stronger order patterns as we enter 2010.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mark, it doesn't seem to see the strength in these numbers today. A question for Mark Rajkowski, perhaps. You talked about the cash build and I look and say, you've now got more than 50% of the quarter's cash sitting there probably earning not a whole lot
componenttext: Mark, it doesn't seem to see the strength in these numbers today. A question for Mark Rajkowski, perhaps. You talked about the cash build and I look and say, you've now got more than 50% of the quarter's cash sitting there probably earning not a whole lot of money. I'm starting to wonder, how much of a cash cushion do you really need? Obviously, you've talked about some incremental investment requirements, but what are you going to do with that lump of cash because ultimately, it's a significant drag on earnings right now?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would say that first of all, I'm not sure we're completely out of the woods yet. The low [ph] trends are improving. Some of the factors I said earlier in my comments are factors that get us a little bit cautious about the U.S. economic recovery. Secondl
componenttext: I would say that first of all, I'm not sure we're completely out of the woods yet. The low [ph] trends are improving. Some of the factors I said earlier in my comments are factors that get us a little bit cautious about the U.S. economic recovery. Secondly, I think just as we did in 2009, we're going to continue to be balanced while maintaining flexibility. So we certainly think maintaining a strong path to our shareholders is important. We're going to look at opportunistically and economically taking down some debt where that make sense. And as I said earlier, we really are not getting ahead of the recovery. We want to put some of that capital to work to profitably grow our business, and take advantage of the market strength that we have in the number of our end markets and geographies.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would just dovetail on that, Mark, and say that what Mark has characterized as a situation that is the very beneficial outcome of uncertainty and a real priority on liquidity that we established at the outset of 2009. We have worked hard, we've accrued
componenttext: I would just dovetail on that, Mark, and say that what Mark has characterized as a situation that is the very beneficial outcome of uncertainty and a real priority on liquidity that we established at the outset of 2009. We have worked hard, we've accrued these levels of cash while maintaining the dividend and managing the debt appropriately and we're actively looking as Mark has indicated, at plans. But I think really before too many triggers of all [ph], it's very, very important to understand the nature and sustainability of any economic recovery as we move through the coming -- hopefully, the coming weeks and the next few months.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think that's obviously fair. My point was more that your internal performance has improved so dramatically that if you're confident in this performance level, that you're starting to get to a point where you're just not going to need a cushion this big.
componenttext: I think that's obviously fair. My point was more that your internal performance has improved so dramatically that if you're confident in this performance level, that you're starting to get to a point where you're just not going to need a cushion this big.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And you can be sure we're thinking about those things. We're not declaring victory either with internal performance. As Mark said, we're gratified. But as we look forward and we're raising the bar on ourselves, we're not satisfied and we've got more to do
componenttext: And you can be sure we're thinking about those things. We're not declaring victory either with internal performance. As Mark said, we're gratified. But as we look forward and we're raising the bar on ourselves, we're not satisfied and we've got more to do as well but the momentum exists.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Gail Glazerman with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Gail Glazerman with UBS.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you please talk a little about how you see inflation moving into 2010 compared to kind of the second half of 2009? And any particular areas that you're concerned about?
componenttext: Can you please talk a little about how you see inflation moving into 2010 compared to kind of the second half of 2009? And any particular areas that you're concerned about?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: We certainly have seen continued benefits from moderating inflation throughout the course of 2009. I think we were about breakeven year-over-year in the first quarter, that ramped up to 12% in the second quarter and I think we are at around 9% in the four
componenttext: We certainly have seen continued benefits from moderating inflation throughout the course of 2009. I think we were about breakeven year-over-year in the first quarter, that ramped up to 12% in the second quarter and I think we are at around 9% in the fourth quarter of this year as we had some easier compares. We do expect to continue to see moderating inflation costs year-over-year in the first quarter but as we move throughout the course of the year, those compares get a little bit tougher and certainly one of the areas that we've got around is freight costs. We expect them to pick up over the course of the year. But all in for 2010, we're expecting a relatively moderate inflation climate. So not a significant increase year-over-year.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think Mark has characterized the dovetail [ph] towards 2010. We're not economists, but as we look out and plan, I think the actions that have been taken in Washington do give us concern about the prospects for inflation to pick up at some point and so l
componenttext: I think Mark has characterized the dovetail [ph] towards 2010. We're not economists, but as we look out and plan, I think the actions that have been taken in Washington do give us concern about the prospects for inflation to pick up at some point and so looking at the model that Mark has outlined, you can be sure that we're going to be very guarded about what could potentially come in the period beyond.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just coming back to the idea of growth. Are we supposed to think of it as kind of more of what you've been doing in terms of the acquisition in Brazil and things like that, or will we expect something maybe a little bit bigger and more dramatic in 201
componenttext: And just coming back to the idea of growth. Are we supposed to think of it as kind of more of what you've been doing in terms of the acquisition in Brazil and things like that, or will we expect something maybe a little bit bigger and more dramatic in 2010?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the others can comment more of what we've been doing, it may sound sort of pedestrian. I think we've got a lot going on and it's been very positive. But I don't think you should expect any dramatic moves, any major moves. What we want to do is we
componenttext: I think the others can comment more of what we've been doing, it may sound sort of pedestrian. I think we've got a lot going on and it's been very positive. But I don't think you should expect any dramatic moves, any major moves. What we want to do is we would continue to build the momentum and the refinement and the execution of our strategy agenda. Again, all geared to generate sustained levels of profitable growth. And that, as you heard Jim described more fully with the Consumer & Office Products acquisition in Brazil could be replicated whether it's in Brazil or in other areas. But we do not have on our screen and therefore don't anticipate any major move.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'll take the lead and Jim can add some more color. We made significant changes in that business' cost structure during the past year. Our overhead cost reductions were upwards of 25% plus year-over-year which were ahead of volume declines. And as Jim sai
componenttext: I'll take the lead and Jim can add some more color. We made significant changes in that business' cost structure during the past year. Our overhead cost reductions were upwards of 25% plus year-over-year which were ahead of volume declines. And as Jim said earlier, we've been really focused on generating cash from that business. So we've stripped out a lot of costs, we've taken out a lot of capacity and year-over-year, it's actually been a positive cash generator. So I think we've made outstanding progress in restructuring that business this year.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think, Mark, as I've noted in my comments on the plastic side of the business, we have seen a competitor or two exits and so we are in a much stronger position there. The print side remains very competitive and if we continue to see further volume decli
componenttext: I think, Mark, as I've noted in my comments on the plastic side of the business, we have seen a competitor or two exits and so we are in a much stronger position there. The print side remains very competitive and if we continue to see further volume declines, we will continue to take the actions necessary to match our capacity with the demand.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: In the past, you have talked about setting the Real Estate business up into a position where market conditions being appropriate, you could potentially spin it or do something whereby it would come a standalone entity. I recognize that marketing condition
componenttext: In the past, you have talked about setting the Real Estate business up into a position where market conditions being appropriate, you could potentially spin it or do something whereby it would come a standalone entity. I recognize that marketing conditions may not be appropriate yet for such an action, but have you put in place the capabilities and have you been putting in place the capabilities, so that when the market timing is appropriate, you could be quickly responsive to it?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mark, let me answer it this way. I think we've put in place great capabilities and we've built strong plans that we're executing on. That should not as an answer, suggest that we've determined what the future structure should be. But we have really built
componenttext: Mark, let me answer it this way. I think we've put in place great capabilities and we've built strong plans that we're executing on. That should not as an answer, suggest that we've determined what the future structure should be. But we have really built a very good business, that is not only generating revenues as we reported today from land sales and is positioned to do so with joint ventures like the Rockefeller Group that is well positioned building on those kinds of joint ventures to capitalize on the commercial, industrial development that is underway in the low country of South Carolina, and maybe spurred further by the moves associated with the Boeing move that Jim talked about. And then more broadly, we still have a series of initiatives underway, not limited to the East Edisto project, which is substantial in its own right to develop similar master plans around which we can build understandings through community engagement and support. And all of this is adding value to that business for MWV shareholders at a time, when as you noted in your question, market conditions more broadly in the United States for real estate are pretty pickled [ph] .

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I certainly understand that no decisions have been made and maybe it belongs as part of the [indiscernible]. At the same time, do you think at one point you could talk about creating standalone capability, so that you would have optionality. I guess just
componenttext: I certainly understand that no decisions have been made and maybe it belongs as part of the [indiscernible]. At the same time, do you think at one point you could talk about creating standalone capability, so that you would have optionality. I guess just the question, would you say at this juncture that the Real Estate business is a standalone business, or is it still integrated pretty significantly into the MeadWestvaco as a whole?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Without implying that it would have a separate structure at least from an entity standpoint, it is increasingly a standalone business as it grows and develops these huge capabilities. Where the integration comes is that we have a Forestry business as a po
componenttext: Without implying that it would have a separate structure at least from an entity standpoint, it is increasingly a standalone business as it grows and develops these huge capabilities. Where the integration comes is that we have a Forestry business as a portion of that, so there's a linkage to our land ownership for those purposes and certainly the fiber supply to our mills. But if you were to look at this from a purely clinical standpoint, the capability that's being built, the business model that is being shaped and the strategy agenda that is being set, arguably would have a separate structure that can stand on its own.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: We've got full capability in that business in terms of management and they've got their own systems. So the answer is yes. They are very much in a position where we could have that optionality.
componenttext: We've got full capability in that business in terms of management and they've got their own systems. So the answer is yes. They are very much in a position where we could have that optionality.

componenttext: That indirectionally, that's right. componenttext: We'll, I think that it would be premature to go beyond that kind of inquiry and speculation, Mark. componenttext: In terms of Calmar and reducing capacity, as we've reported in previous calls, we did a lot of work this year in terms of improving our supply chain there both closing facilities and also bringing on additional manufacturing capacity in low cost country, regions, as well as some outsourcing that we've been doing. componenttext: Our performance-based comp was higher this year as we exceeded our targets. We had a very strong year.
