headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's John. We are conducting a wide range of analysis in Brazil because of the strength Brazil represents to us. As you know, we've been there for almost 60 years, and it's been a solid growing and very, very profitable business for us. At the present tim
componenttext: It's John. We are conducting a wide range of analysis in Brazil because of the strength Brazil represents to us. As you know, we've been there for almost 60 years, and it's been a solid growing and very, very profitable business for us. At the present time as we announced, among other things, we're evaluating the potential to add capacity to our mill and tray spars that would all be designed to add more adequately and efficiently utilize infrastructure that we largely have in place and in the process. We integrate our Corrugated business which is growing nicely in the local markets. The market strength there over the past few years, has been particularly good, and with the strength that Brazil almost uniquely has in the world today, we're seeing good growth, particularly for the profitable differentiated products that we've produced now and projected over time. So we're looking hard at what the future opportunities for us in Brazil can and should be, both strategically and opportunistically. But at the core of that right now is the evaluation of the capacity addition at the tray spars mill. We're in the early stages of that, while the work is very, very good, we're on schedule to hopefully, meet the target that we have broadly set for completing this analysis at the end of this calendar year.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then, it looks like you bought back some stock in the quarter. Can you just update me on what's left under your authorization and then how you're prioritizing buybacks with capital investments like the one potentially in Brazil with dividends and acqu
componenttext: And then, it looks like you bought back some stock in the quarter. Can you just update me on what's left under your authorization and then how you're prioritizing buybacks with capital investments like the one potentially in Brazil with dividends and acquisitions as well?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, Claudia, this is Mark. We repurchased about $26 million worth of stock in the quarter, that was about 1.1 million shares. We have approximately 1 million shares that remain under that current authorization. And as we look at deploying cash, I think
componenttext: Sure, Claudia, this is Mark. We repurchased about $26 million worth of stock in the quarter, that was about 1.1 million shares. We have approximately 1 million shares that remain under that current authorization. And as we look at deploying cash, I think we're going to continue to remain balanced. We're going to continue to remain disciplined. I think that approach has served us well. And we do see opportunities to profitably grow our business. You referenced Brazil and that is one example.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And when you think about your sort of targeted debt levels, are you pretty much where you want to be? Or do you have a hope to sort of delever more or do you say you're under-levered?
componenttext: And when you think about your sort of targeted debt levels, are you pretty much where you want to be? Or do you have a hope to sort of delever more or do you say you're under-levered?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're slightly under 40% debt-to-cap and we're pretty comfortable with that amount of leverage. And as you know, looking at our maturity schedule, we don't have any significant maturities due for the next two or three years. So we're in a pretty good spot
componenttext: We're slightly under 40% debt-to-cap and we're pretty comfortable with that amount of leverage. And as you know, looking at our maturity schedule, we don't have any significant maturities due for the next two or three years. So we're in a pretty good spot right now.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And next we'll go to the line of Gail Glazerman with UBS.
componenttext: And next we'll go to the line of Gail Glazerman with UBS.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to get some color, the $25 million operating hit in the Packaging resource, that included actual operations but also input cost associated with the weather?
componenttext: I just wanted to get some color, the $25 million operating hit in the Packaging resource, that included actual operations but also input cost associated with the weather?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Gail, it's Jim. That's right, it's really a function of several things. One is simply higher input costs where we're having to reach much further out to get wood. We had several situations where based on the lack of wood, we actually had to slow back oper
componenttext: Gail, it's Jim. That's right, it's really a function of several things. One is simply higher input costs where we're having to reach much further out to get wood. We had several situations where based on the lack of wood, we actually had to slow back operations. And then lastly, with the lack of wood, pulping less, you have less internal generated energy from black liquor, so we had gotten -- used more fossil fuel to run the operations. The combination of those three elements represented about $25 million in cost to us in the quarter.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is it fair to say that the majority of that would disappear in the second quarter with the weather improved? Or kind was the kind of wood cost the biggest component of that?
componenttext: Is it fair to say that the majority of that would disappear in the second quarter with the weather improved? Or kind was the kind of wood cost the biggest component of that?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: With what we've seen and what we are forecasting. I would say about half of that will disappear but we're staring at probably a $12 million to $13 million hit with what we see today for the quarter.
componenttext: With what we've seen and what we are forecasting. I would say about half of that will disappear but we're staring at probably a $12 million to $13 million hit with what we see today for the quarter.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Also I just wanted to get some more color on your demand outlook. I appreciate -- the second half, is still a while away but your caution, is that just truly based on macro? Or is there anything you're seeing from your customer order patterns or you're he
componenttext: Also I just wanted to get some more color on your demand outlook. I appreciate -- the second half, is still a while away but your caution, is that just truly based on macro? Or is there anything you're seeing from your customer order patterns or you're hearing from your customers or you're seeing from your inventories that makes you particularly cautious about the second half demand outlook?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Gail, I'll take that up, it's John. I think across the board, it really is the fact that our customers are telling us that their visibility is limited. I don't think there are any factors that we're seeing in our markets that are creating concerns for our
componenttext: Gail, I'll take that up, it's John. I think across the board, it really is the fact that our customers are telling us that their visibility is limited. I don't think there are any factors that we're seeing in our markets that are creating concerns for our customers or indeed for us. It's just that with the macro factors that we're all facing, visibility remains limited and we'll probably have a clearer picture as we move through the middle of May and into the end of May and see what July and thereafter begins to look like. So I think, there's just a good deal of caution and a tread lightly attitude across all of our markets.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Do you have any read into what they've been doing with inventory? Are they still keeping those quite lean or at this point with the demand that you've seen to date, do you think some of that's been inventory restocking?
componenttext: Do you have any read into what they've been doing with inventory? Are they still keeping those quite lean or at this point with the demand that you've seen to date, do you think some of that's been inventory restocking?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: What I'm seeing, and I'll ask Jim to comment more, what I'm hearing is that inventories have been managed reasonably tightly and leanly, that there is no major restocking efforts. So the sales that we're generating represent real underlying demand.
componenttext: What I'm seeing, and I'll ask Jim to comment more, what I'm hearing is that inventories have been managed reasonably tightly and leanly, that there is no major restocking efforts. So the sales that we're generating represent real underlying demand.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jim, in Consumer Solutions, I just want to confirm, you were pretty confident last quarter talking about the pass throughs and being much more secure than I guess in 2008. Is that still the case? Has anything changed given the inflation we've seen this ye
componenttext: Jim, in Consumer Solutions, I just want to confirm, you were pretty confident last quarter talking about the pass throughs and being much more secure than I guess in 2008. Is that still the case? Has anything changed given the inflation we've seen this year?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, there's a little bit of a -- I missed a part, was that resin costs?
componenttext: I'm sorry, there's a little bit of a -- I missed a part, was that resin costs?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is the pass throughs in consumer solutions?
componenttext: Is the pass throughs in consumer solutions?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We clearly -- through the quarter and into the second quarter are seeing significant increases in our resin costs and so that's impacting our inflation picture. A large majority of that business does have contractual pass throughs but they are delayed eit
componenttext: We clearly -- through the quarter and into the second quarter are seeing significant increases in our resin costs and so that's impacting our inflation picture. A large majority of that business does have contractual pass throughs but they are delayed either a quarter or two. So the increases that we saw in Q1, we will begin -- we'll recover those, begin to recover those in Q2. Having said that, we've seen some increases in Q2 that will begin to recover in Q3 as well.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: But are you still comfortable that you're better positioned to cope with that than you were back in 2008?
componenttext: But are you still comfortable that you're better positioned to cope with that than you were back in 2008?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. We've done a lot of work over the course of the last 12 to 18 months to restructure our customer contract and protect ourselves and we are much in a better position than we were in 2008.
componenttext: Absolutely. We've done a lot of work over the course of the last 12 to 18 months to restructure our customer contract and protect ourselves and we are much in a better position than we were in 2008.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And next we'll go to the line of Mark Wilde of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And next we'll go to the line of Mark Wilde of Deutsche Bank.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010

componenttext: And wondered if you could talk a little bit about the SBS market right now. There were some price increases that were realized in the trade papers this weekend and I just wonder how that rolled through for you guys across your bleached board portfolio in the second quarter and beyond?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: If you'll note on our slides, our pricing moved up to about $30 a ton in Q1, year-over-year. As you know, we are moving pricing at the end of this month and aren't actively doing that right now. We have high confidence that prices will begin, will move ev
componenttext: If you'll note on our slides, our pricing moved up to about $30 a ton in Q1, year-over-year. As you know, we are moving pricing at the end of this month and aren't actively doing that right now. We have high confidence that prices will begin, will move even further as a result of these announcements. But at this point, it's still early in the process and so I wouldn't want to predict what that's going to be.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: There's enough in your business if I recall, Jim, that's on longer-term contracts that we really wouldn't want to take that $40 and just slap that on to our second quarter realization. Is that correct?
componenttext: There's enough in your business if I recall, Jim, that's on longer-term contracts that we really wouldn't want to take that $40 and just slap that on to our second quarter realization. Is that correct?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's correct and most of that -- that business all moved in the first quarter and you wouldn't apply all that across the board, for sure.
componenttext: That's correct and most of that -- that business all moved in the first quarter and you wouldn't apply all that across the board, for sure.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And also in the SBS environment, it sounds like some of the other players are reporting long backlogs and very tight supplies. I just wondered whether there is any potential for you if the market remains tight to bring up any of the idle machines either a
componenttext: And also in the SBS environment, it sounds like some of the other players are reporting long backlogs and very tight supplies. I just wondered whether there is any potential for you if the market remains tight to bring up any of the idle machines either at Evadale or Covington?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, there's no potential we would do that.
componenttext: No, there's no potential we would do that.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Turning to Brazil, just to kind of follow on, I know that you're trying to kind of leverage some of the capital that you've spent around the middle down there over the last several years. Just to take advantage of that without adding any more beyond a mac
componenttext: Turning to Brazil, just to kind of follow on, I know that you're trying to kind of leverage some of the capital that you've spent around the middle down there over the last several years. Just to take advantage of that without adding any more beyond a machine, what kind of scale would that put us in?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We haven't really designed exactly what the machine is going to do, Mark. We will not add significant infrastructure capital. We'll have to do a little bit down there. But to your point whether it's around power generation or pulp mill, we're pretty well
componenttext: We haven't really designed exactly what the machine is going to do, Mark. We will not add significant infrastructure capital. We'll have to do a little bit down there. But to your point whether it's around power generation or pulp mill, we're pretty well set. And so we will design the machine to take full advantage of that but not spend significant capital beyond what we've already done on the back-end infrastructure.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jim, how much extra pulping capacity is there at the mill right now?
componenttext: Jim, how much extra pulping capacity is there at the mill right now?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mark, we could design probably somewhere around a 300,000 ton machine. It all depends on basis weights and other things but we could support that with the pulping capacity we have today, some OCC and other things and that's initial thought of what we're t
componenttext: Mark, we could design probably somewhere around a 300,000 ton machine. It all depends on basis weights and other things but we could support that with the pulping capacity we have today, some OCC and other things and that's initial thought of what we're thinking about.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Are you also down there, Jim, are you investing in Brazil or beyond in the Corrugated business? Because the market is growing.
componenttext: Are you also down there, Jim, are you investing in Brazil or beyond in the Corrugated business? Because the market is growing.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: It is and that's clearly something we are looking at. We've been growing with that market. We put a new box plan up in the Northeast a couple of years ago. We really like the integrated model that we have down there from forestry through the corrugated bo
componenttext: It is and that's clearly something we are looking at. We've been growing with that market. We put a new box plan up in the Northeast a couple of years ago. We really like the integrated model that we have down there from forestry through the corrugated boxes. And so as part of this, we certainly will be evaluating how and where we might grow the corrugated businesses as well.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I would just jump on there Mark and say, as you know, knowing South America as well as you do, Brazil is -- we're seeing good consumer growth and we're seeing with all the foreign investment going in good industrial growth and all of that is translati
componenttext: And I would just jump on there Mark and say, as you know, knowing South America as well as you do, Brazil is -- we're seeing good consumer growth and we're seeing with all the foreign investment going in good industrial growth and all of that is translating into a very strong outlook for continued growth in the corrugated markets.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, if you just look at what's happening in other packaging markets down there, it really is pretty dramatic. Last question I have, Charleston, are you guys feeling any impact yet from the announcement by Boeing to move Dreamliner production down there?
componenttext: Yes, if you just look at what's happening in other packaging markets down there, it really is pretty dramatic. Last question I have, Charleston, are you guys feeling any impact yet from the announcement by Boeing to move Dreamliner production down there? Is that bringing in, sort of other suppliers, or secondary, tertiary suppliers that might be interested in sighting on some of your property?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the broad answer to that question, Mark, is yes. I think the work that was under way to encourage the Boeing expansion, as well as broad-based work by the South Carolina ports, not to mention other good economic development work down there as in w
componenttext: I think the broad answer to that question, Mark, is yes. I think the work that was under way to encourage the Boeing expansion, as well as broad-based work by the South Carolina ports, not to mention other good economic development work down there as in what is across the country been a very weak real state market and I would underscore the Charleston area is not immune. But the Charleston area has benefited by all of these actions and directly, or indirectly, we felt a little bit of lift in the tide.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And any sense, John, on when we'll -- as analysts and investors people that, like perhaps look at what you're doing down there, get a little more color on that?
componenttext: And any sense, John, on when we'll -- as analysts and investors people that, like perhaps look at what you're doing down there, get a little more color on that?

componenttext: Great question and I think the story is developing very nicely and we would look for the opportunity, if provided that opportunity. I won't want to pick a date right now but thanks for the prompt and we'll take that into our plans.

componenttext: We'll go next to the line of Mark Weintraub of Buckingham Research.

componenttextpreview: On the tax rate, Mark, what should we be thinking of for the balance of the year?
componenttext: On the tax rate, Mark, what should we be thinking of for the balance of the year?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're looking at the 25% to 27% effective tax rate, Mark.
componenttext: We're looking at the 25% to 27% effective tax rate, Mark.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then I was hoping -- can we get a little bit more breakdown on the $82 million in productivity gains that you showed year-over-year, is there a way to categorize them? And also, how much is yet to come from actions that you've already taken?
componenttext: And then I was hoping -- can we get a little bit more breakdown on the $82 million in productivity gains that you showed year-over-year, is there a way to categorize them? And also, how much is yet to come from actions that you've already taken?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'll take that. Really in late 2008, we started on a full prolonged approach to go after productivity. And as you know, we've made a significant effort to drive our overhead structure and reduce fixed costs. We worked very hard on a sourcing initiative to
componenttext: I'll take that. Really in late 2008, we started on a full prolonged approach to go after productivity. And as you know, we've made a significant effort to drive our overhead structure and reduce fixed costs. We worked very hard on a sourcing initiative to drive down input costs. We consolidated, or closed 16 facilities around the globe to get our infrastructure where we needed it to be. And we've had a very strong operating excellence program out of our mill-based businesses that we've taken and driven that through all the businesses now and begin to take it around the globe. So all elements of that were components of what helped drive the performance in Q1. You can think about it that probably, $30 million of the $82 million was flow through from last year, and the remaining $50 million or so, are actions that we've taken this year. And we'll continue to build on this program as we go throughout the rest of this year.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And so from actions that you have taken recently, how much would you say is -- how much would you be targeting to improve relative to what we already saw in the first quarter if that's a fair way to look at it?
componenttext: And so from actions that you have taken recently, how much would you say is -- how much would you be targeting to improve relative to what we already saw in the first quarter if that's a fair way to look at it?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me take the piece of it that relates to the actions that we took last year related to overhead and capacity rationalization. Last year, we delivered over $150 million of bottom line cost reduction. As Jim said in the first quarter this year, we saw mo
componenttext: Let me take the piece of it that relates to the actions that we took last year related to overhead and capacity rationalization. Last year, we delivered over $150 million of bottom line cost reduction. As Jim said in the first quarter this year, we saw more than $30 million of additional cost takeout related to those programs. And as we said last year, we continued to expect the full run rate benefit of those programs to be $250 million cost reduction. So we're $185 million into that $250 million.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And how did you get that $185 million -- so I can't just take the $82 million and times by four and be at $320 million?
componenttext: And how did you get that $185 million -- so I can't just take the $82 million and times by four and be at $320 million?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, Mark, because as Jim was saying, in that $80 million, you have a combination of sources of productivity. You have productivity driven from cost actions related to overhead, manufacturing capacity rationalization, as well as a tremendous amount of work
componenttext: No, Mark, because as Jim was saying, in that $80 million, you have a combination of sources of productivity. You have productivity driven from cost actions related to overhead, manufacturing capacity rationalization, as well as a tremendous amount of work that Jim and the team are doing around, driving sourcing benefits and operating productivity in the plants.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: So the $250 million, it's a -- I think I understand.
componenttext: So the $250 million, it's a -- I think I understand.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: The $250 million gets back to the programs we started last year around overhead reduction and manufacturing capacity rationalization.
componenttext: The $250 million gets back to the programs we started last year around overhead reduction and manufacturing capacity rationalization.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: If the weather is better and the first quarter $25 million hit was a function of bad weather, I'm not quite sure why you don't get the full $25 million back in the second quarter.
componenttext: If the weather is better and the first quarter $25 million hit was a function of bad weather, I'm not quite sure why you don't get the full $25 million back in the second quarter.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: A part of that was related to -- we still have some tough weather in April, especially down in Evadale, Texas. We're having to rebuild inventory with more expensive wood just to get back to where we can continue to operate. That's about what the impact is
componenttext: A part of that was related to -- we still have some tough weather in April, especially down in Evadale, Texas. We're having to rebuild inventory with more expensive wood just to get back to where we can continue to operate. That's about what the impact is going to be, and we feel pretty confident...

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think fundamentally, the way I look at it Mark, is that you've got a little bit of weather hang over and you've got some catch up that's required just to get things back to normal.
componenttext: I think fundamentally, the way I look at it Mark, is that you've got a little bit of weather hang over and you've got some catch up that's required just to get things back to normal.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then by the third quarter -- so basically you get half of it back in the second quarter and the balance in the third quarter assuming the weather behaves itself?
componenttext: And then by the third quarter -- so basically you get half of it back in the second quarter and the balance in the third quarter assuming the weather behaves itself?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right.
componenttext: Right.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Next we'll go to the line of Mark Connelly of CLSA.
componenttext: Next we'll go to the line of Mark Connelly of CLSA.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: When I look at your Consumer Solutions business and the gives and takes this quarter, clearly, some of the businesses you've invested in more recently that are hopefully higher growth and certainly higher margin are kicking in and you're throwing out some
componenttext: When I look at your Consumer Solutions business and the gives and takes this quarter, clearly, some of the businesses you've invested in more recently that are hopefully higher growth and certainly higher margin are kicking in and you're throwing out some of the lower stuff. Should we expect that to sort of be an ongoing cleansing process, where the top line isn't growing as much as the margins are? Or are you going to take more discrete steps to rebalance that portfolio towards the higher end?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me start with that, and Jim, or Mark can chime in, Mark. I think that there will always be a weeding out process since markets change and some become more attractive and others become less so. But I think as you look at this, which I think is the esse
componenttext: Let me start with that, and Jim, or Mark can chime in, Mark. I think that there will always be a weeding out process since markets change and some become more attractive and others become less so. But I think as you look at this, which I think is the essence of your question, you can look at it with the view that we've taken a pretty aggressive approach over the course of the past 12 months, so the major weeding has been done and the focus now is on pursuing strategic initiatives in those areas we see as representing significant opportunity for profitable growth.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: My second question is, how, with all the gains you've gotten in cost and productivity, how do you get comfortable that you're going to be able to hold on to all of that as business starts to come back and the pressure for reinvestment starts to kick back
componenttext: My second question is, how, with all the gains you've gotten in cost and productivity, how do you get comfortable that you're going to be able to hold on to all of that as business starts to come back and the pressure for reinvestment starts to kick back in?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Again, let me offer a couple of comments here at a high level. That is all part of the new operating discipline that is -- that we're committed to maintaining. We view growth investment as something that is going to be important to our future, both to sup
componenttext: Again, let me offer a couple of comments here at a high level. That is all part of the new operating discipline that is -- that we're committed to maintaining. We view growth investment as something that is going to be important to our future, both to support the strategic agenda I referred to in your first question, and we're looking to fund that by continuing to ensure that we're disciplined in taking all unnecessary cost out of the system while continuing to improve overall productivity. Of course, there will be investments in SG&A, particularly related to market development activity, and there will be the capital requirements that we've talked about at a high level earlier in this call. But we would look to ensure that the productivity benefits, the leanness that we're building into our system at all levels is looked to be maintained.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I might just add to that, I think while we are pleased with the progress that we've been able to make to date, we're certainly not satisfied. We see continued opportunities as John said, to drive further productivity improvements, and that really is w
componenttext: And I might just add to that, I think while we are pleased with the progress that we've been able to make to date, we're certainly not satisfied. We see continued opportunities as John said, to drive further productivity improvements, and that really is what we're about. And so we see further opportunities for improving our cost structure.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, John, I'd say that certainly that's our expectation through the course of this year. And the other part of this is what John and Jim were talking about before which is really capitalizing on investments we have made in innovation in the commercial si
componenttext: Yes, John, I'd say that certainly that's our expectation through the course of this year. And the other part of this is what John and Jim were talking about before which is really capitalizing on investments we have made in innovation in the commercial side to bring new profitable products to the marketplace. So this is not just a cost play. We do have more room in terms of margin expansion on the cost side but we also expect to continue to grow profitably with new products and enter in new markets.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010

componenttext: And then just maybe shifting to the financial side of the question, Mark, is there any reason that the cash balance continues to kind of hang at the kind of $500 million more than what you've historically run at? I know you talked about a disciplined approach to deploying capital and maintaining a balanced approach, but is there any reason that you wouldn't be more aggressive in deploying that capital over the next 12 to 18 months?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think as I said, we're going to be balanced and disciplined. And certainly, we are looking for opportunities to profitably grow our business, and where we see those and one example as I mentioned before and we've talked about, is certainly Brazil.
componenttext: Well, I think as I said, we're going to be balanced and disciplined. And certainly, we are looking for opportunities to profitably grow our business, and where we see those and one example as I mentioned before and we've talked about, is certainly Brazil. And we certainly will look to continue to provide a good strong return to our shareholders. So I think that there's nothing that's going to be imminent that's going to suck up all that cash, we're going to continue to play it as a we have and expect to be very balanced and disciplined in deploying that capital.

componenttext: Rick I'd just add to what Mark -- by saying is we've emphasized this morning, we're very encouraged by the progress we're making. But again, considering Mark's response, which I think reflects where we are, visibility is limited and as we assess opportunities and we have greater visibility, we'll be in the position to make more clear decisions with respect to timing and use of resources that's logical to deploy.

componenttext: I think if you go back and look at last year, we've had a steady March in improved margins in this business, and that continued through Q1. Obviously, a big part of it is the capacity utilization, we're able to put a lot more volume through our existing facilities. We're able to take advantage of some of the focused investments we've made over the last couple of years. So a lot of things came together to drive the improvement.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Quewee, and good morning, everyone. This morning, we announced our results before the market opened. The notification in this morning's call was broadly disclosed. Further, this morning's call is being webcast at mwv.com, and slides that accompany
componenttext:
Thanks, Quewee, and good morning, everyone. This morning, we announced our results before the market opened. The notification in this morning's call was broadly disclosed. Further, this morning's call is being webcast at mwv.com, and slides that accompany this call are available there as well.
I'll briefly remind you that certain statements we make are forward-looking and are not guarantees of future performance, and are subject to known and unknown risks and uncertainties described in our public filings. Furthermore, contents contain time-sensitive information that although correct today, may change with the passage of time.
First, a brief recap of the results we reported this morning. For the first quarter, we reported net income of $24 million or $0.14 per share. This includes net favorable after-tax items, totaling $5 million or $0.03 per share. Now, here to tell you more about our results for the first quarter are John Luke, Chairman and CEO; Jim Buzzard, our President; and Mark Rajkowski, CFO. I'll turn the call over to John.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jason, and good morning. MWV had another solid performance in the first quarter. Our positive earnings performance outpaced not only last year's first quarter but also the same pre-recession periods in 2008 and 2007. It represents a fourth consecu
componenttext:
Thanks, Jason, and good morning. MWV had another solid performance in the first quarter. Our positive earnings performance outpaced not only last year's first quarter but also the same pre-recession periods in 2008 and 2007. It represents a fourth consecutive quarter of earnings growth directly attributable to our market participation and business model improvement strategies, demonstrating that we are on the right track and are continuing to create a fundamentally more profitable company, capable of generating consistent higher returns for shareholders.
It is these areas of strategic focus that will position us for greater profitability in the near term, well in advance of any full economic recovery. With these strategies and some modest improvement in demand in the first quarter, we increased volume compared to last year, including both share gains and increased orders in many of our targeted markets. We increased sales for our higher value solutions for Personal Care, Healthcare and Home and Garden Packaging, and we captured share gains with paperboard and the food service, tobacco and commercial print markets. 
We are also making significant gains in many of our Specialty Chemicals and Consumer & Office Products markets, and Jim will provide more detail in just a moment about these and other highlights across the company.
With the operating leverage we've created over the past year, having eliminated more than $185 million of structural costs, this improvement in volume had a beneficial impact on our earnings performance during the quarter. The progress we have driven is gratifying, and the underlying signs of market improvement compared to a year ago are welcome. That said, general market demand still remains well below peak 2007 levels, and it remains uncertain whether the present improvement trend is durable or just temporary. 
While we hope that the current trajectory continues, we are continuing to plan for sustained softness. In either of that, we will continue to execute the strategy that has helped us deliver successful results throughout this challenging economic environment. Specifically, we will continue to shape and execute our market participation strategies to ensure that we are driving our own destiny, creating opportunities for profitable growth with innovative products like MWare, Promina and Shellpak, with investments and enhanced strategies in emerging markets like Brazil and China, and with continued emphasis on overhead cost reductions and manufacturing productivity.
With still limited visibility into what economic and market conditions may be in the second half of this year, these areas of emphasis will continue to be the biggest contributors to our success. Across MWV today, we have significant positive momentum and are moving forward with pace and purpose. We're more profitable due to our disciplined strategist to improve our revenue mix, exit low-return business and close unprofitable facilities. 
We're more competitive in targeted markets, having launched innovative new products and expanded in the right geographies. We're more efficient and effective, having reduced costs, significantly improved manufacturing productivity and augmented our organization with new talent and capabilities, and our financial strength is both sound and continues to build. We remain on the right path to make MW be a fundamentally more profitable company and a more valuable investment, both in today's still soft and uncertain economy and in more prosperous times ahead.
I'd now like to turn the call over to Jim Buzzard, to talk about our business results in the first quarter, before Mark discusses our financial metrics and provides a more detailed outlook for the second quarter. Jim?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. This was one of our strongest quarters to start the year in recent memory, as we often report a small loss in the seasonally slow period.Compared to the first quarter last year, we've extended our positive earnings momentum with a signific
componenttext:
Thanks, John. This was one of our strongest quarters to start the year in recent memory, as we often report a small loss in the seasonally slow period.
Compared to the first quarter last year, we've extended our positive earnings momentum with a significantly improved cost structure from ongoing actions, increased operating productivity in our facilities, share gains with targeted products and some increase in demand in key markets. These are the things we've been focused on in each of our businesses for more than a year, and the impact continues to show in our overall results.
During the quarter, we generated important commercial momentum from our participation strategies, gaining share with targeted products and growing our positions in emerging markets. And for the first time since economic crisis began, demand trends turn upward in certain of our markets. I'll highlight some of the specific trends in each of our businesses in just a moment. But overall, the result was a 5% increase in volume across the company.
Along with the impact of our ongoing cost reduction and productivity actions, this top line growth helped drive adjusted EBIT, up 97% for the first quarter. We added more than $30 million of additional cost savings during the first quarter, to the $154 million we completed to the end of 2009. With this leverage and a sequential growth trends we experienced through the first quarter, we believe our earnings progress can continue in the second quarter and the positive impact should be even greater as demand grows.
Let me share some detail about the commercial trends and operating highlights in each of our businesses in consumer packaging markets. As always, you'll find additional information in the slide presentation that accompanies this call.
In the Packaging Resources business, segment profit was higher than last year, as volumes recovered and pricing gains and productivity actions at our mills drove an increase in earnings. This came during a difficult quarter for our operations due to adverse weather conditions. Unseasonably cold and wet weather reduced fiber availability across the industry, which resulted in significantly higher input costs and lost productivity. Despite these challenges, which had about a $25 million negative impact in our results, the segment earned $30 million during the quarter. This was almost 60% higher than last year and nearly as much as the first quarter of 2008.
Compared to the first quarter of last year, shipments of SBS were up to 3%. We outperformed the broader market in key segments including commercial prints, tobacco, and food service grades. Our MWare line of paperboard for recyclable and compostable food-service applications, such as cups and plates, has been particularly strong. CNK volumes were up 5% compared to last year, as demand began to recover for both beverage and food packaging around the world, and as we continued to make gains with recently added food customers.
Volume was also up in Brazil, as the economy there has shown a solid recovery. As a result, we're Rigesa generated a strong profit growth with higher sales and improved productivity. Overall, paperboard demand in Packaging Resources remain strong as we began the second quarter, with backlogs currently between five and six weeks.
The Consumer Solutions segment had another strong quarter, its fifth straight period of year-over-year earnings growth. Profits rose to $21 million during the quarter, more than a 50% increase compared to last year due to productivity improvements, a stronger mix of high-return products and gains in targeted packaging markets. The actions we took to eliminate some low-return business from our portfolio brought overall sales down slightly compared to last year.
Let me go through each of the consumer packaging markets we serve in this business to give you a sense of the performance in the quarter. In Our Global Beverage business, sales and earnings were modestly lower, with an unfavorable impact related to further realignment of our manufacturing footprint in Western Europe and North America. As these initiatives come to a close, we expect to see added productivity benefits as we move through 2010.
Lower beverage volumes in the first quarter were primarily due to unseasonably cool weather in North America in January and February. We've partially offset this impact with double-digit growth in the Asia-Pacific region, led by our major beer customers, and by increased volumes in Australia and New Zealand.
More recent sales trends have improved notably. Seasonally stronger volumes are running above year-ago levels at major beer and carbonated soft drink customers in the United States and Europe. Part of what we're seeing is pipeline billing from very low a year ago levels, were also seeing more regular and larger orders, suggesting some demand stabilization for the near term.
We also continue to see good volume trajectory in Asia with major customers, and we'll begin to benefit from new wins with yogurt customers in China. This is an area we've recently targeted for portfolio growth and are expecting increase in contributions to our business as we move through the year.
In our Healthcare business, earnings increased during the first quarter, primarily because of the choices we've made to emphasize Shellpak and other adherence solutions, and from strong productivity improvement. In the first quarter last year, we produced about $13 million units for Wal-Mart prescription drug program. This year, that number is up to almost $25 million. There are currently 12 drugs being sold in Shellpak at Wal-Mart pharmacy counters and we expect that to grow this year as well.
Sales were also steady for our oral and nasal pumps in the Healthcare market, with growth in the over-the-counter market, as well as for our specialty preservative free pumps that addresses specific regulatory need in Europe. 
The personal care markets continue to improve, and as a result, our business increased sales and earnings substantially compared to a particularly weak first quarter last year, when our customers aggressively destocked inventory. Our customers are now sounding more confident, and that has translated into stronger orders for higher value fragrance dispensers, skincare airless products and luxury secondary packaging in Europe. We are gaining share in each of these categories by adding new customers, as well as by adding to our business with existing customers like P&G, Unilever, L'Oreal and J&J.
With this improving demand trends, we expect to continue our positive trajectory through the third quarter, as this market rebound from historical lows last year. 
Volumes are good for our targeted products in the home and garden market, primarily in the United States, especially the more profitable custom applicators for lawn and garden maintenance, and trigger sprayer for surface cleansers. The important spring garden season is off to a strong start, with retailers reporting increased traffic and good sell-through to the higher promotional activity by the branded industry leaders. And we're seeing solid growth for our next generation aerosol trigger, with the new and existing customers.
Overall, sales and earnings were down slightly despite this market progress in home and garden, as we again eliminated some of our offerings to focus more profitable products, and were impacted by higher resin costs that we expect to recoup through contractual pass throughs over the next quarter or two. 
In the Media business, sales and earnings were lower than last year. We're managing to generate as much cash we possibly can from this business, and doing so successfully, by continuing to drive productivity improvements and aggressively targeting categories and customers that are still profitable.
Turning to our non-packaging businesses, our positive earnings momentum continued in the first quarter for both the Consumer & Office Products and Specialty Chemicals segment. The Consumer & Office Products segment had one of its best first quarter performances, earning $6 million in the quarter that traditionally loses money, as we build toward the North American back-to-school season later in the year. Sales of time management and other consumer products were higher to our retail and commercial partners, and good sell through for school supplies in Brazil by the stronger replenishment orders late in the first quarter. Sales in the quarter were up 7% and included benefits from last year's acquisition of Grafons. Productivity across all of this segment's businesses, especially in the United States, coupled with the stronger volume led to solid year-over-year earnings improvement. 
Sales increased significantly on Specialty Chemicals segment compared to a very weak quarter last year, and the business posted strong earnings of $25 million for the first quarter. This segment saw volume recover strongly across key product lines, in both pine chemicals and activated carbon. We had strong performances in adhesives and oil field services, continue to grow the Asphalt Additives business, especially in China and Brazil, and saw a rebound in carbon volume due to an increase in auto production in North America.
This volume increases helped improve asset utilization rates, and along with that, overall segment earnings. The Community Development and Land Management segment earned $23 million in the first quarter, including $17 million from 21 real estate transactions that closed during the first three months of the year. 
And with volume and pricing higher for pulpwood and sawtimber during the quarter, our forestry operations earned an additional $6 million. While conditions in the real estate sector are still very difficult, we have some positive trends for both our rural land tracts and industrial and development sites. We completed a number of rural land tract transaction in the Charleston, South Carolina area. And these mix of properties contributed to a higher per acre value during the quarter of about $4,300. 
In addition to an uptick in the number of sales during the quarter, the volume and quality of inquiries for these rural tracts was higher on our retail land website. And having recently unveiled the master plan for East Edisto, we are in negotiation with two potential tenants for the commerce part that is part of the first phase of development. Now I'd like to turn the call over to Mark to discuss some of our financial metrics for the first quarter. Mark?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim. The momentum on our market participation and business model strategies that John and Jim have described is helping us create a fundamentally more profitable company that we believe can continue to generate sustainable performance improvement
componenttext:
Thanks, Jim. The momentum on our market participation and business model strategies that John and Jim have described is helping us create a fundamentally more profitable company that we believe can continue to generate sustainable performance improvement over the long term. In the first quarter, our progress was clearly reflected in many of our financial metrics, including the following highlights.
Overall, sales grew 4% with volume increases driven by our new products, share gains in targeted markets and continued strong growth in emerging markets. Our operating profit essentially doubled due to the combination of our improved cost structure and successful growth strategies. We have a strong balance sheet with a total debt-to-capital ratio of below 40% and substantial cash reserves, that enable us to continue to profitably grow our business and provide strong returns to our shareholders.
Let me provide a bit more detail on each of these measures of our progress during the first quarter. On the top line, our overall sales growth was 4%, excluding the large land sale last year and product line exits related to our market participation strategies, comparable first quarter sales increased approximately 10%, consisting of about 5% of volume improvement and 5% of FX benefits in other items.
While overall volume benefited modestly from the demand improvement we experienced in the quarter, well more than half the increase came from the success we are seeing with our growth strategies. New products in the quarter accounted for over 16% of total first quarter revenue, including a strong rebound in demand for recently launched fragrance and airless dispensing products, as well as continued strength in our Shellpak product for prescription drugs. We also saw share gains in higher value paperboard grades like commercial print and in our Specialty Chemicals market. 
In the 22% sales increase from emerging markets we saw in the quarter was driven by recovery in volumes in Brazil and continued strong growth for beverage packaging and asphalt additives in China.
Increased sales and the continued benefit of our productivity and overhead cost actions resulted in year-over-year improvement of 250 basis points in our operating profit. First quarter adjusted earnings before interest and taxes almost doubled versus last year to $73 million. Our strong performance is being driven by the ongoing execution of strategies to fundamentally improve the company's underlying profitability. Importantly, we expect to further leverage our improved cost base and expand margins as we continue to profitably grow our business.
Taking a closer look at the key performance drivers, both adjusted gross margin and SG&A saw a continued solid year-over-year improvement. First quarter adjusted gross margin improved by almost 100 basis points versus the first quarter of 2009 to 17.5%. This includes absorbing approximately 190 basis points of negative, weather-related impacts at the mills during the quarter.
Adjusted SG&A decreased 9% on an absolute basis versus the prior year and was 12.5% of sales, an improvement of 170 basis points versus the year-ago quarter. Moving to the balance sheet, our financial position and flexibility remain excellent. At the end of the quarter, total cash was $731 million. Our net debt-to-capital ratio was 30% and our pension plan was a more than 140% funded.
Cash flow used by operations was approximately $8 million in the quarter. Significant cash earnings in a 2.5 day improvement in our cash-to-cash cycle were more than offset by incentive compensation payments. As we move through the year, we expect cash flow from operations to significantly improve. And for the full year, we expect to achieve another year of positive free cash flow, which we define as cash flow from operations, after CapEx and dividends.
With respect to deploying our cash resources, we will continue to made our balanced approach. Over the past three years, we've generated about $3 billion of discretionary cash flow from operations and asset sales. Over this period, we have reinvested about a third of this cash back into the business. We've returned about a third to shareholders through a strong dividend in periodic share repurchases. And we have used a third to repay debt and build up our cash resources during the economic crisis. These priorities remain the same as we move forward. 
Now turning to our outlook for the second quarter. We saw improving demand trends during the first quarter, and given current order rates and backlogs, we expect these trends to continue through the second quarter. Beyond that however, there is less certainty as order patterns into the second half of the year will depend on retail sell-through levels, which are subject to the risk related to continued high levels of unemployment and shifts in consumer confidence. 
That said, we are continuing to position our businesses to capture growth and bring more of it to the bottom line. Our commercial strategies are working. We have good confidence in our more competitive business model, and we are continuing to selectively reinvest profitable growth opportunities across our businesses.
We will, however, be watching commodity inflation, which we expect will tick up through the year and could accelerate if demand trends move higher than the current trajectory. But we will, of course, continue to seek pricing to offset these impacts.
With that as context, I'll now provide some segment-specific comments for the second quarter, starting with Packaging Resources. We're expecting segment profit to be solidly above last year. Backlogs at the mills are currently running well above year-ago levels and the combination of better demand with an improved product mix and higher productivity levels are the main drivers of our positive outlook. In addition, we expect continued profit growth at Rigesa. Rising input costs will partially offset these positive factors in the near term, including lingering fiber inflation trends from the weather-related issues in the first quarter, as well as inflation for some commodity chemicals and outbound freight. We are however, continuing to implement pricing actions to offset the negative impacts from cost inflation.
In the Consumer Solutions group, segment profit is expected to be solidly above year-ago levels. Improved results will be driven by a continued demand recovery through the current quarter for targeted products across our Personal Care, Home and Garden and Healthcare Packaging businesses as well as seasonal strength in beverage, which we started to see in March. We also expect to see higher pricing to recapture resin inflation, as well as continued productivity gains.
Turning to the Consumer & Office Products segment, we are expecting another solid overall back-to-school season. We are, however, expecting profit to be modestly lower than last year's very strong second quarter performance. While the business will continue to benefit from strong productivity gains and cost reductions, as is the case with this business, the timing of selling and the ultimate sell through to the consumer of the segment back-to-school products can significantly impact the level of revenues and profits during the quarter.
In Specialty Chemicals, we expect another strong quarter with significant year-over-year improvement. Benefits from continued demand recovery across pine chemical and activated carbon markets and higher productivity levels are expected to drive substantially improved earnings. However, inflation in certain raw materials and freight cost will partially offset these positive factors in the near term.
Finally, in the Community Development and Land Management segment, the timing of land sales, which is the key near-term driver results, remains difficult to forecast. However, we do expect modestly improved segment profit versus the year-ago quarter. The level of improvement will continue to depend on the amount, timing and mix of the land we sell in the quarter.
In summary, during the second quarter, we expect to extend our record solid year-over-year earnings growth and margin improvement. While demand trends are improving, it's important to keep in mind that in most cases, our volumes are still well off peak 2007 levels. The improvements we're driving are largely the result of continued execution of our strategies to improve our business model. With that, I'll turn it back over to John.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark. In summary, the first quarter was another strong one for MWV, with continued momentum from our market participation and business model improvement strategies. We are benefiting from progress we have driven in our targeted markets, as well as
componenttext: Thanks, Mark. In summary, the first quarter was another strong one for MWV, with continued momentum from our market participation and business model improvement strategies. We are benefiting from progress we have driven in our targeted markets, as well as some early stage general market improvement. And we will remain on the path that we have established for long-term profitable growth, continuously refining our participation in the most attractive markets and improving the efficiency and effectiveness of our business model. The impact is already apparent in our improved earning results. And we are committed to continuing to deliver higher profitability and additional value to our shareholders. This concludes our prepared remarks this morning and we'd now be happy to address your questions.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's John. We are conducting a wide range of analysis in Brazil because of the strength Brazil represents to us. As you know, we've been there for almost 60 years, and it's been a solid growing and very, very profitable business for us. At the present tim
componenttext: It's John. We are conducting a wide range of analysis in Brazil because of the strength Brazil represents to us. As you know, we've been there for almost 60 years, and it's been a solid growing and very, very profitable business for us. At the present time as we announced, among other things, we're evaluating the potential to add capacity to our mill and tray spars that would all be designed to add more adequately and efficiently utilize infrastructure that we largely have in place and in the process. We integrate our Corrugated business which is growing nicely in the local markets. The market strength there over the past few years, has been particularly good, and with the strength that Brazil almost uniquely has in the world today, we're seeing good growth, particularly for the profitable differentiated products that we've produced now and projected over time. So we're looking hard at what the future opportunities for us in Brazil can and should be, both strategically and opportunistically. But at the core of that right now is the evaluation of the capacity addition at the tray spars mill. We're in the early stages of that, while the work is very, very good, we're on schedule to hopefully, meet the target that we have broadly set for completing this analysis at the end of this calendar year.

componenttext: I just wanted to get some color, the $25 million operating hit in the Packaging resource, that included actual operations but also input cost associated with the weather?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Gail, it's Jim. That's right, it's really a function of several things. One is simply higher input costs where we're having to reach much further out to get wood. We had several situations where based on the lack of wood, we actually had to slow back oper
componenttext: Gail, it's Jim. That's right, it's really a function of several things. One is simply higher input costs where we're having to reach much further out to get wood. We had several situations where based on the lack of wood, we actually had to slow back operations. And then lastly, with the lack of wood, pulping less, you have less internal generated energy from black liquor, so we had gotten -- used more fossil fuel to run the operations. The combination of those three elements represented about $25 million in cost to us in the quarter.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: With what we've seen and what we are forecasting. I would say about half of that will disappear but we're staring at probably a $12 million to $13 million hit with what we see today for the quarter.
componenttext: With what we've seen and what we are forecasting. I would say about half of that will disappear but we're staring at probably a $12 million to $13 million hit with what we see today for the quarter.

componenttext: Gail, I'll take that up, it's John. I think across the board, it really is the fact that our customers are telling us that their visibility is limited. I don't think there are any factors that we're seeing in our markets that are creating concerns for our customers or indeed for us. It's just that with the macro factors that we're all facing, visibility remains limited and we'll probably have a clearer picture as we move through the middle of May and into the end of May and see what July and thereafter begins to look like. So I think, there's just a good deal of caution and a tread lightly attitude across all of our markets.

componenttext: We clearly -- through the quarter and into the second quarter are seeing significant increases in our resin costs and so that's impacting our inflation picture. So the increases that we saw in Q1, we will begin -- we'll recover those, begin to recover those in Q2. Having said that, we've seen some increases in Q2 that will begin to recover in Q3 as well.

componenttext: Mark, we could design probably somewhere around a 300,000 ton machine. It all depends on basis weights and other things but we could support that with the pulping capacity we have today, some OCC and other things and that's initial thought of what we're thinking about.

componenttext: And I would just jump on there Mark and say, as you know, knowing South America as well as you do, Brazil is -- we're seeing good consumer growth and we're seeing with all the foreign investment going in good industrial growth and all of that is translating into a very strong outlook for continued growth in the corrugated markets.

componenttextpreview: And then I was hoping -- can we get a little bit more breakdown on the $82 million in productivity gains that you showed year-over-year, is there a way to categorize them? And also, how much is yet to come from actions that you've already taken?
componenttext: And then I was hoping -- can we get a little bit more breakdown on the $82 million in productivity gains that you showed year-over-year, is there a way to categorize them? And also, how much is yet to come from actions that you've already taken?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'll take that. Really in late 2008, we started on a full prolonged approach to go after productivity. And as you know, we've made a significant effort to drive our overhead structure and reduce fixed costs. We worked very hard on a sourcing initiative to
componenttext: I'll take that. Really in late 2008, we started on a full prolonged approach to go after productivity. And as you know, we've made a significant effort to drive our overhead structure and reduce fixed costs. We worked very hard on a sourcing initiative to drive down input costs. We consolidated, or closed 16 facilities around the globe to get our infrastructure where we needed it to be. And we've had a very strong operating excellence program out of our mill-based businesses that we've taken and driven that through all the businesses now and begin to take it around the globe. So all elements of that were components of what helped drive the performance in Q1. You can think about it that probably, $30 million of the $82 million was flow through from last year, and the remaining $50 million or so, are actions that we've taken this year. And we'll continue to build on this program as we go throughout the rest of this year.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And so from actions that you have taken recently, how much would you say is -- how much would you be targeting to improve relative to what we already saw in the first quarter if that's a fair way to look at it?
componenttext: And so from actions that you have taken recently, how much would you say is -- how much would you be targeting to improve relative to what we already saw in the first quarter if that's a fair way to look at it?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me take the piece of it that relates to the actions that we took last year related to overhead and capacity rationalization. Last year, we delivered over $150 million of bottom line cost reduction. As Jim said in the first quarter this year, we saw mo
componenttext: Let me take the piece of it that relates to the actions that we took last year related to overhead and capacity rationalization. Last year, we delivered over $150 million of bottom line cost reduction. As Jim said in the first quarter this year, we saw more than $30 million of additional cost takeout related to those programs. And as we said last year, we continued to expect the full run rate benefit of those programs to be $250 million cost reduction. So we're $185 million into that $250 million.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And how did you get that $185 million -- so I can't just take the $82 million and times by four and be at $320 million?
componenttext: And how did you get that $185 million -- so I can't just take the $82 million and times by four and be at $320 million?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, Mark, because as Jim was saying, in that $80 million, you have a combination of sources of productivity. You have productivity driven from cost actions related to overhead, manufacturing capacity rationalization, as well as a tremendous amount of work
componenttext: No, Mark, because as Jim was saying, in that $80 million, you have a combination of sources of productivity. You have productivity driven from cost actions related to overhead, manufacturing capacity rationalization, as well as a tremendous amount of work that Jim and the team are doing around, driving sourcing benefits and operating productivity in the plants.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: So the $250 million, it's a -- I think I understand.
componenttext: So the $250 million, it's a -- I think I understand.

componenttext: The $250 million gets back to the programs we started last year around overhead reduction and manufacturing capacity rationalization.

componenttext: A part of that was related to -- we still have some tough weather in April, especially down in Evadale, Texas. headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: When I look at your Consumer Solutions business and the gives and takes this quarter, clearly, some of the businesses you've invested in more recently that are hopefully higher growth and certainly higher margin are kicking in and you're throwing out some
componenttext: When I look at your Consumer Solutions business and the gives and takes this quarter, clearly, some of the businesses you've invested in more recently that are hopefully higher growth and certainly higher margin are kicking in and you're throwing out some of the lower stuff. Should we expect that to sort of be an ongoing cleansing process, where the top line isn't growing as much as the margins are? Or are you going to take more discrete steps to rebalance that portfolio towards the higher end?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me start with that, and Jim, or Mark can chime in, Mark. I think that there will always be a weeding out process since markets change and some become more attractive and others become less so. But I think as you look at this, which I think is the esse
componenttext: Let me start with that, and Jim, or Mark can chime in, Mark. I think that there will always be a weeding out process since markets change and some become more attractive and others become less so. But I think as you look at this, which I think is the essence of your question, you can look at it with the view that we've taken a pretty aggressive approach over the course of the past 12 months, so the major weeding has been done and the focus now is on pursuing strategic initiatives in those areas we see as representing significant opportunity for profitable growth.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: My second question is, how, with all the gains you've gotten in cost and productivity, how do you get comfortable that you're going to be able to hold on to all of that as business starts to come back and the pressure for reinvestment starts to kick back
componenttext: My second question is, how, with all the gains you've gotten in cost and productivity, how do you get comfortable that you're going to be able to hold on to all of that as business starts to come back and the pressure for reinvestment starts to kick back in?

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Again, let me offer a couple of comments here at a high level. That is all part of the new operating discipline that is -- that we're committed to maintaining. We view growth investment as something that is going to be important to our future, both to sup
componenttext: Again, let me offer a couple of comments here at a high level. That is all part of the new operating discipline that is -- that we're committed to maintaining. We view growth investment as something that is going to be important to our future, both to support the strategic agenda I referred to in your first question, and we're looking to fund that by continuing to ensure that we're disciplined in taking all unnecessary cost out of the system while continuing to improve overall productivity. Of course, there will be investments in SG&A, particularly related to market development activity, and there will be the capital requirements that we've talked about at a high level earlier in this call. But we would look to ensure that the productivity benefits, the leanness that we're building into our system at all levels is looked to be maintained.

headline: MeadWestvaco Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I might just add to that, I think while we are pleased with the progress that we've been able to make to date, we're certainly not satisfied. We see continued opportunities as John said, to drive further productivity improvements, and that really is w
componenttext: And I might just add to that, I think while we are pleased with the progress that we've been able to make to date, we're certainly not satisfied. We see continued opportunities as John said, to drive further productivity improvements, and that really is what we're about. And so we see further opportunities for improving our cost structure.

componenttext: First on the Consumer Solutions business, is there a step change coming in the margins that we should anticipate given the strategic things you've done and the productivity efforts that you've made? Or is this kind of a long-term mid-single digit kind of margin business?

componenttext: We certainly will look to continue with the initiatives we have in improving our market position, the areas that we've targeted, as well as continuing to look to lean out the costs wherever we can to improve the margins.
